title: The Real Journey: Choosing Your Starter & Building Your Pokémon Team
description: A chill take on picking your starter Pokémon and building a team that actually feels like yours — not just what the meta says.
fullContent:
It Always Starts With One Question

You boot up a new Pokémon game. Fresh save file. New region. New adventure.

And then it hits you.

"So… who's my starter?"

This single decision somehow feels way more important than it should. You know you'll catch hundreds of Pokémon later, but your starter? That one sticks with you.

How Most of Us Actually Pick Our Starter (Be Honest)

Let's not pretend this is some calculated strategic choice. Most players fall into one of these:

  • "Fire types look sick" (always valid)
  • "This one's cute"
  • "I already googled the final evolution"
  • "This guy carried me last time"
  • "My friend already called the other two"

And honestly? All of these reasons are completely fine.

There Is No Wrong Starter

This needs to be said louder for the people in the back.

There is no objectively wrong starter Pokémon.

Game Freak literally designs these games so you can beat the story with any starter. You're not gonna get stuck because you didn't pick the "optimal" one.

Pick what feels right. Pick what looks cool. Pick based on pure vibes.

SHUT UP AND PICK THE FIRE TYPE

Why Starters Are Emotional, Not Logical

Your starter is with you from Route 1 all the way to the Pokémon League. They get overleveled. They clutch fights they probably shouldn't win. They faint at the absolute worst times.

They become part of your Pokémon identity.

Years later, you might forget half your team — but you'll always remember your starter.

Building a Team: Meta vs Meaning

Once the game opens up, the next question hits:

"Okay so what should my actual team be?"

This is where people split into two groups:

  • Google "best team for [game name]"
  • Catch whatever looks cool

Honestly? The best teams are somewhere in the middle.

Type Coverage Matters (But Not That Much)

Yeah, having decent type coverage helps. It sucks getting swept by a random Ice or Fairy gym.

But you don't need perfect coverage to have fun.

If you vibe with a Pokémon, you'll make it work. That's just how it goes.

Every Team Has "That Pokémon"

You know the one.

  • Not the strongest stat-wise
  • Definitely not meta
  • But you refuse to box it

That Pokémon earns its spot through clutch moments, not spreadsheets.

Every memorable team has at least one.

Ultra Moon Was Something Else

Some Pokémon games are good.

Some are memorable.

And then there's Pokémon Ultra Moon.

Alola just hit different. The Totem battles actually made you think. The vibe, the soundtrack, the story — everything clicked.

Ultra Moon especially nailed that sweet spot between challenge and fun without making Pokémon feel like competitive esports.

Let's Talk About Gengar

Every trainer has that one Pokémon.

Mine? Gengar.

Fast. Ghost-type. Slightly unhinged. Absolutely perfect.

Gengar slots into basically any team and still feels special every time. Whether it's outspeeding threats, landing clutch Shadow Balls, or just vibing with maximum menace energy — it never gets old.

Some Pokémon are strong.

Some Pokémon have personality.

Gengar? Both.

Switch Era Pokémon Just Hits Different

Playing Pokémon on the Switch still feels kinda surreal.

Bigger worlds. Actual good graphics. Quality-of-life stuff that should've existed years ago. And yet — it's still Pokémon at its core.

You're still out here catching creatures, battling trainers, and getting emotionally attached to pixels.

Some things never change. And honestly? That's fine.

Final Take: Just Play Your Way

Don't let tier lists ruin your experience.

Don't feel bad for picking a starter just because it "looks cool".

Don't box your favorite Pokémon because some guide said it's not optimal.

The best Pokémon team isn't the one with perfect stats.

It's the one you actually remember years later.

Pick your starter. Build your team. Have fun.

That's literally the whole point.
